message_1:
Sure! Here's a Hill Cipher problem:

Suppose you have the plaintext message "MATH" and you want to encrypt it using the Hill Cipher with the matrix key 
$$
\left[ \begin{matrix}
2 & 3 \\
1 & 4
\end{matrix} \right]
$$

Convert the message to numerical values (using A=0, B=1,..., Z=25) and pad it with an ‘X’ to make the length of the message a multiple of 2. Then use the Hill Cipher to encrypt the message. Finally, convert the resulting ciphertext back to letters. What is the final encrypted message?
message_2:
First, we convert the plaintext message "MATH" to numerical values using A=0, B=1, ..., Z=25:

M = 12
A = 0
T = 19
H = 7

Since the length of the message is already a multiple of 2, we don't need to pad it with an 'X'. Now, we will use the Hill Cipher to encrypt the message. We will multiply the matrix key by the numerical values of the message in pairs:

$$
\left[ \begin{matrix}
2 & 3 \\
1 & 4
\end{matrix} \right]
\left[ \begin{matrix}
12 \\
0
\end{matrix} \right]
=
\left[ \begin{matrix}
24 \\
12
\end{matrix} \right]
$$

$$
\left[ \begin{matrix}
2 & 3 \\
1 & 4
\end{matrix} \right]
\left[ \begin{matrix}
19 \\
7
\end{matrix} \right]
=
\left[ \begin{matrix}
41 \\
40
\end{matrix} \right]
$$

Now, we will take the results modulo 26:

$$
\left[ \begin{matrix}
24 \\
12
\end{matrix} \right]
\mod{26}
=
\left[ \begin{matrix}
24 \\
12
\end{matrix} \right]
$$

$$
\left[ \begin{matrix}
41 \\
40
\end{matrix} \right]
\mod{26}
=
\left[ \begin{matrix}
15 \\
14
\end{matrix} \right]
$$

Finally, we convert the resulting ciphertext back to letters:

24 = Y
12 = M
15 = P
14 = O

So, the final encrypted message is "YMPO".
